entry.et: Middle English streme, from Old English strēam; akin to Old High German stroum stream, Greek rhein to flow

def.dt: :a body of running water (as a river or brook) flowing on the earth
:any body of flowing fluid (as water or gas)
:a steady succession (as of words or events) kept up an endless stream of chatter
:a constantly renewed or steady supply a stream of revenue
:a continuous moving procession a stream of traffic
:an unbroken flow (as of gas or particles of matter)
:a ray of light
:a prevailing attitude or group has always run against the stream of current fashion
:a dominant influence or line of development the influence of two streams of inheritance: genetic and cultural P. B. Baltes
:track 3c
:to flow in or as if in a stream
:to leave a bright trail a meteor streamed through the sky
:to exude a bodily fluid profusely her eyes were streaming
:to become wet with a discharge of bodily fluid streaming with perspiration
:to trail out at full length her hair streaming back as she ran
:to pour in large numbers complaints came streaming in
:to emit freely or in a stream his eyes streamed tears
:to display (as a flag) by waving
:the continuous unedited chronological flow of conscious experience through the mind
:interior monologue
:a long narrow meandering current of high-speed winds near the tropopause blowing from a generally westerly direction and often exceeding a speed of 250 miles (402 kilometers) per hour
:of, relating to, or being music that incorporates elements of classical music and jazz
village NE Illinois W of Chicago pop 40,438
warm current in North Atlantic flowing from Gulf of Mexico NE along United States coast to Nantucket & thence eastward
village SE New York on Long Island pop 36,368
